questions.text: A 46-year-old obese man comes to the emergency room because of paresthesias in his feet and a hypopigmented skin lesion on his knee that he first noticed 6 weeks ago. He has also had fever, fatigue, and malaise for the last week. He has a history of chronic autoimmune thyroiditis for which he takes levothyroxine. He immigrated from Indonesia 3 years ago to join his family in the United States. His temperature is 38.7째C (101.7째F) and blood pressure is 122/84 mm Hg. Physical exam shows a well-defined hypopigmented skin lesion approximately 3 cm in diameter over the anterior aspect of the right knee. The area has no hair growth and remains dry although he is diaphoretic. There is diminished sensation to light touch and pinprick in the skin lesion when compared to surrounding skin. There is reduced light touch sensation in the big toes bilaterally. A full-thickness skin biopsy confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hydroxychloroquine is used in the treatment of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which may manifest with hypopigmented skin lesions and peripheral neuropathy. Anhidrotic skin lesions with reduced sensation are not commonly seen in SLE. Furthermore, SLE often involves other organs such as the kidneys.

B) INCORRECT:

Sodium stibogluconate is an antibiotic used in the treatment of cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL), which can manifest with painless, hypopigmented skin lesions. However, CL does not cause neuropathy and is not endemic to Indonesia.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical fluconazole is used to treat fungal infections, which can lead to hypopigmented skin lesions (e.g., tinea versicolor). However, these infections do not commonly cause peripheral neuropathy or anhidrotic lesions. Moreover, fungal infections usually manifest with pruritus.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical betamethasone can be used to treat a wide variety of skin conditions, including vitiligo. Vitiligo manifests with painless depigmented skin lesions and is commonly associated with other autoimmune diseases, such as autoimmune thyroiditis. However, this patient also presents with peripheral neuropathy and hypoesthetic skin lesions, which are not typically seen in vitiligo.

E) INCORRECT:

IV amphotericin can be used to treat leishmaniasis and severe systemic fungal infections, either of which can manifest with hypopigmented skin lesions. However, peripheral neuropathy and anhidrotic skin lesions with reduced sensation are not commonly seen in these conditions.

F) CORRECT:

The combination of rifampicin and dapsone is the treatment of choice for leprosy, which is a slowly progressive, chronic infectious disease caused by prolonged exposure to Mycobacterium leprae. Leprosy primarily occurs in tropical regions (e.g., India, Indonesia, Brazil) and is rarely seen in the US. The three cardinal clinical signs of leprosy are hypopigmented skin lesions, nerve thickening, and peripheral nerve palsies. However, the clinical manifestations vary depending on the type of leprosy. This patient most likely has tuberculoid leprosy, which is characterized by a small number of hypopigmented and anhidrotic skin lesions (rarely more than 3). Hypoesthesia of the skin develops in later stages.

Lepromatous leprosy is characterized by multiple symmetrical macules, plaques, and/or nodules. This form of leprosy is treated with a combination of rifampicin, dapsone, and clofazimine.
Image Description:

Multiple, partly confluent hypopigmented patches with erythematous borders are visible on the patient's back.
questions.hint: The presence of peripheral neuropathy and a hypopigmented, anhidrotic, hairless, and hypoesthetic skin lesion in a patient who recently emigrated from Indonesia suggests leprosy.

questions.text: An investigator studying immune response administers a 0.5 mL intradermal injection of an autoclaved microorganism to a study volunteer. Four weeks later, there is a 12-mm, indurated, hypopigmented patch over the site of injection. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the observed skin finding?

choices.text: Increased antibody production by B cells
Increased activity of CD4+ Th1 cells
Increased release of transforming growth factor beta

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Macrophages increase uptake of lipids in response to IL-10 released from regulatory T cells that are recruited to the antigenic site in lepromatous leprosy. This increased lipid uptake leads to the histopathologic finding of foamy macrophages full of leprosy bacilli. However, the lepromin test performed here does not detect foamy macrophages.

B) INCORRECT:

An increase in CD4+ Th2 cells is characteristic in patients with lepromatous leprosy. It leads to a B cell response and an increased production of antibodies. These antibodies are, however, not protective but cause immune-mediated damage. The lepromin test performed here does not provoke an increase in antibody production.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased activity of neutrophils is a crucial step in an antimicrobial reaction and part of the immunopathology of lepromatous leprosy. It causes erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL), a type 2 complication of leprosy, in which the neutrophil infiltration leads to an immune-complex reaction forming the pathognomonic skin lesions. However, the lepromin test performed here does not trigger ENL.

D) CORRECT:

A lepromin skin test is used to differentiate between lepromatous leprosy and tuberculoid leprosy. The test measures the individual's ability to mount an effective cell-mediated immune response against M. leprae. This immune response activates CD4+ Th1 cells, which subsequently activate cytotoxic T-cells, causing inflammation with granuloma formation (induration). A positive test with induration indicates adequate cell-mediated immune response and confirms tuberculoid leprosy, whereas a negative test indicates weak cell-mediated immunity and confirms lepromatous leprosy.

E) INCORRECT:

Transforming growth factor beta is released by regulatory T cells in lepromatous leprosy and suppresses the immune response to M. leprae exposure. However, the lepromin test performed here does not measure the release of transforming growth factor beta.
questions.hint: The physician has performed a lepromin test, which involves intradermally injecting a small amount of autoclaved Mycobacterium leprae (the causative organism of leprosy) and assessing the skin reaction after 3 to 4 weeks. An area of induration > 5 mm at that time is defined as a positive result. It indicates that the body is able to mount an immune response following exposure to the organism.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to the physician because of a hypopigmented skin lesion on his finger. He first noticed it 4 weeks ago after cutting his finger with a knife while preparing food. He did not feel the cut. For the past week, he has also had fever, fatigue, and malaise. He has not traveled outside the country since he immigrated from India to join his family in the United States 2 years ago. His temperature is 38.7째C (101.7째F). Physical examination shows a small, healing laceration on the dorsal aspect of the left index finger and an overlying well-defined, hypopigmented macule with raised borders. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is decreased over this area. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative bacillus that can cause a number of skin conditions, including ecthyma gangrenosum, which classically develops in immunocompromised patients with P. aeruginosa bacteremia. Over the course of 12 to 18 hours, affected patients develop painless red macules that quickly indurate and then become pustules, vesicles, and/or bullae, after which they evolve into crusted, gangrenous ulcers. Although the gangrenous ulcers may be hypoesthetic, the patient in this vignette is not immunosuppressed, and his lesions did not develop so quickly.

B) INCORRECT:

Epidermophyton floccosum is a dermatophyte fungus that causes diseases such as tinea pedis (athlete's foot), tinea cruris, tinea corporis, and onychomycosis. Dermatophyte lesions are scaly and erythematous; although they may be hypopigmented, they would be pruritic rather than hypoesthetic.

C) CORRECT:

Leprosy, or Hansen disease, is an infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, whose three cardinal clinical manifestations are hypopigmented skin lesions, nerve thickening, and peripheral nerve palsies. Leprosy has two subtypes: lepromatous leprosy and tuberculoid leprosy. The patient's solitary, hypopigmented, hypoesthetic macule is characteristic of tuberculoid leprosy. Diagnosis is usually confirmed with biopsy. Treatment consists of prolonged multi-drug therapy with dapsone and rifampin. Clofazimine is added to the therapeutic regimen in patients with multibacillary leprosy.
Image Description:

Multiple, partly confluent hypopigmented patches with erythematous borders are visible on the patient's back.

D) INCORRECT:

Leishmania donovani is the pathogen responsible for leishmaniasis, which is transmitted by a sandfly bite. The cutaneous form of leishmaniasis is characterized by reddish macules and papules around the bite that may progress to central ulceration. The incubation time of the disease is weeks to months. Although the disease is endemic to India, this patient has not been outside the US for 2 years, so he is very unlikely to have leishmaniasis. In addition, the lesions of leishmaniasis are not typically hypoesthetic.

E) INCORRECT:

Malassezia furfur causes tinea versicolor, which is characterized by round, well-demarcated macules of variable coloration that can coalesce into irregular patches. Although tinea versicolor can cause hypopigmented lesions, these lesions would be mildly pruritic rather than hypoesthetic.
questions.hint: A hypoesthetic, hypopigmented macular lesion in a patient originally from a developing country is highly suggestive of Hansen disease, a condition associated with stigma for much of recorded history.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man, originally from Haiti, presents with scattered skin nodules that have increased in number during the past 6 to 9 months. He has twice visited the emergency department, where he received antibiotics that did not relieve his symptoms. He reports diminished sensation within the lesions but no pain.
On examination, scattered nodules are evident on his distal extremities (figure).
Which one of the following tests is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Culture of a skin swab from a lesion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypoesthetic, hypopigmented macules are not consistent with porphyria.

B) INCORRECT:

No accurate serologic test to diagnose leprosy is commercially available.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypoesthetic, hypopigmented macules are not consistent with heavy-metal poisoning.

D) INCORRECT:

The diagnosis of leprosy is based on biopsy of skin lesions, as M. leprae does not grow in culture in media.

E) CORRECT:

Leprosy (Hansen disease) is caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which targets skin and nerves. Presentations vary but classically involve hypopigmented lesions with areas of hypoesthesia. Infection may cause permanent nerve damage. Although the mode of transmission is poorly understood, it is likely via nasal droplets and prolonged contact. However, most people who are exposed do not develop the disease. Countries such as India and Brazil carry the highest burden of disease, but cases are still diagnosed in the United States, mostly in immigrants. Cases also occur rarely in the southern U.S., where armadillos are known to be a reservoir of infection.

Underrecognition of signs and symptoms of leprosy can delay diagnosis. The diagnosis of leprosy is based on biopsy of skin lesions, as M. leprae does not grow in culture in media. Only a skin biopsy that is found to contain acid-fast bacilli (that are usually extremely sparse) in nerves can establish the diagnosis definitively. No accurate serologic test to diagnose leprosy is commercially available.

Leprosy is curable. Treatment involves a long course of dapsone and rifampin, with or without clofazimine, depending on the classification of the disease.

Key learning point: The most appropriate diagnostic test for suspected leprosy (Hansen disease) is a skin biopsy.
